instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-01401A: What is 820-01401A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.USBC_XB_CC1: What is USBC_XB_CC1? USBC_XB_CC1 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 19.5v on one usb and 5.17v on the other
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot
        19.5v 0.22A and 4.36w on one 
and 5.17v 0.03A and 0.18w
 
[ATTACH type="full"]60417[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 19.5v on one usb and 5.17v on the other
threads.message:
Hey ,

This is what i have right now, my Mac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01401A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
on UB300 and UB400 20.2v with 110mA .
on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> 5v with 380mA-390mA.

i guess that the 1.<SIGNAL>1V_LDO</SIGNAL> rail of the 19.5v is present and in the other ( 5.17v) is not.
Did you check for short on the 1.<SIGNAL>1V_LDO</SIGNAL> rail ? Does the other LDO voltages of the ACE are presents ?

edit: Now i see that its on the same side different USB C port . But as i see it , the one with the 20V is the Master ACE chip and the other one is the slave .
so maybe you have a problem in communication between them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 19.5v on one usb and 5.17v on the other
threads.message:
Compare diode mode to ground on CC1/2 pins between both ports.
Inspect USB-C terminals for corrosion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 19.5v on one usb and 5.17v on the other
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 19.5v on one usb and 5.17v on the other
threads.message:
Check all resistors from pages 29/30.
If all good, go for ones in page 28.
